October 15, 1913.
Simon Flexner, M. D.,
The Rockefeller Institute
For Medical Research,
66th St. & Avenue A.,
New York, N. Y.
My dear Doctor Flexner:-
div1.p:
Form No. 128, S.G.O.
(Write nothing in this space.)
(Attach this end.)

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt
of your letter of the 14th instant addressed to General Torney. I
note your inquiry with reference to a photograph of Walter Reed that
would be suitable for framing and hanging in the Institute library.
In reply I would say that there are photographs in existence from
one of which two enlarged negatives have been made. These are at the
Army Medical School. One of them is approximately 5 x 7 inches; the
other 10 x 12 inches. A print from the latter is now hanging in this
office. I have instructed Captain Christie who is in charge of photo-
graphic work at the Army Medical School, to make you a print from each

(Write nothing in this space.)
3--2536 (Attach this end.)

of these and forward the same to you. I trust these will reach you safely
at an early date.

I think that every member of the Medical Corps will feel gratified
when they learn that the portrait has a place in your library, and those of us
who knew and loved Reed will deeply appreciate this tribute to him. May I
feel at liberty to give to the service papers an item to the effect that
the portrait will be so hung?
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely, CHAS. M. GANDY CMG
Acting Surgeon General, U. S. Army.
